questions.text: All of the following are features of otitis media with effusion EXCEPT?

options.label: A
options.text: Most cases have Ad type of curve on tympanometry and a conductive hearing loss

options.label: B
options.text: Usually occurs after an episode of common cold, but can occur without it also

options.label: C
options.text: Resolves on its own after the symptoms subside

questions.correct_answer: A. Most cases have Ad type of curve on tympanometry and a conductive hearing loss
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Most cases have Ad type of curve on tympanometry and a conductive hearing loss Otitis media with effusion presents with conductive hearing loss but the curve in tympanometry is a B curve and not Ad curve Hence, this statement is false

Highyeild:

Otitis media with effusion: Secretory otitis media or ‘Glue ear” Insidious condition in which there is thick or sticky non-purulent fluid behind the eardrum in the middle ear, but there is no ear Fluid in the middle ear is sterile. Clinical features The only presenting symptom may be hearing loss with fullness in Otoscopic findings of SOM – Air bubbles on the surface of the eardrum. Fluid behind the Dullness of the eardrum when a light is used, with loss of light Retracted eardrum with decreased Treatment Watchful Waiting - Active monitoring of the condition and hearing for about three months Surgery – Recommended in case of non-resolution of SOM. Myringotomy and aspiration of fluid: An incision is made in tympanic membrane and fluid as with Grommet (ventilation tube): In case of recurrence following myringotomy, a grommet is inserted to provide continued aeration of middle This is the most common surgical intervention for SOM. Most preferred site of grommet insertion is antero-inferior. Surgical treatment of causative factor: Adenoidectomy, tonsillectomy etc.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options: B, C and D. are true about otitis media with effusion

questions.text: Which of the following is not recommended in an 8 yrs old child with B/L SNHL?

options.label: D
options.text: Sitting in front row of the class

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Adenoidectomy & Grommet insertion Adenoidectomy and grommet insertion is done in children with conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion

Highyeild:

Indications of Myringotomy and grommet insertion Acute suppurative otitis media. Severe earache with bulging tympanic membrane. Incomplete resolution with opaque drum and persistent conductive deafness. Complications of acute otitis media, e.g. facial paralysis, labyrinthitis or meningitis with bulging tympanic membrane. Recurrent acute otitis media. Otitis media with effusion. Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the eustachian tube). Atelectatic ear (grommet is often inserted for long-term aeration).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Hearing aid-It is a treatment modality in cases of Bilateral SNHL in children Option: C. Cochlear implant-It is a treatment modality in cases of Bilateral SNHL in children Option: D. Sitting in front row of the class-This is done to improve concentration and decrease the hearing distance, but not the treatment of choice

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset lower motor neuron facial paralysis on his left side. Radiological tests showed no deficits. What is the next best step in management?

options.label: B
options.text: Steroids, Acyclovir and eye patching and eye ointment

questions.correct_answer: B. Steroids, Acyclovir and eye patching and eye ointment
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Steroids, Acyclovir and eye patching and eye ointment Sudden onset lower motor neuron palsy is mostly due to a viral infection which is known as Bell’s palsy The 1st line of treatment for this are steroids, antivirals and eye care

Highyeild:

Bell’s palsy It is defined as idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis or paresis of acute onset Aetiology Viral Infection. Vascular Ischaemia. Hereditary. Autoimmune Disorder. Clinical Features Onset is sudden. Patient is unable to close his eye. On attempting to close the eye, eyeball turns up and out (Bell phenomenon). Saliva dribbles from the angle of mouth. Face becomes asymmetrical. Tears flow down from the eye (epiphora). Paralysis may be complete or incomplete. Some complain of noise intolerance(stapedial paralysis) or loss of taste (involvement of chorda tympani). Diagnosis. All other known causes of peripheral facial paralysis should be excluded. Careful history, complete otological and head and neck examination, X-ray studies, blood tests such as total count, peripheral smear, sedimentation rate, blood sugar and serology. Nerve excitability tests are done daily or on alternate days and compared with the normal side to monitor nerve degeneration. Topodiagnostic tests Treatment General Reassurance. Relief of ear pain by analgesics. Care of the eye Physiotherapy or massage of the facial muscles gives psychological support to the patient. Steroids Antivirals

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Intravenous antibiotics, and mastoidectomy-This is not useful as it is not caused by bacterial infection or COM Option: C. Electrical stimulation of facial nerve-This is necessary after the 1st line treatment with steroids and antivirals Option: D. Facial nerve decompression-This is done when the patient has no improvement with conservative management

questions.text: Which of the following is typically not seen in Allergic rhinitis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Otto veraguth folds Otto veracity fold is an omega shaped skin fold between the eyelids It is seen in melancholy and chronic depression

Highyeild:

Allergic rhinitis Signs of allergy may be seen in the nose, eyes, ears, pharynx or larynx. Nasal signs include transverse nasal crease—a black line across the middle of dorsum of nose due to constant upward rubbing of nose simulating a salute (allergic salute), pale and oedematous nasal mucosa which may appear bluish. Turbinates are swollen. Thin, watery or mucoid discharge is usually present. Ocular signs include oedema of lids, congestion and cobble-stone appearance of the conjunctiva, and dark circles under the eyes (allergic shiners). Otologic signs include retracted tympanic membrane or serous otitis media as a result of eustachian tube blockage. Pharyngeal signs include granular pharyngitis due to hyperplasia of submucosal lymphoid tissue. A child with perennial allergic rhinitis may show all the features of prolonged mouth breathing as seen in adenoid hyperplasia. Laryngeal signs include hoarseness and oedema of the vocal cords.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A- Allergic salute-a black line across the middle of dorsum of nose due to constant upward rubbing of nose simulating a salute Option: B- Allergic shiners-Dark circles under the eyes due to rubbing of eyes because of allergy Option: C- Dennie-morgan line - They are extra creases/lines below the lower eyelid due to allergy All these are features of allergy

questions.text: A 13 year old male patient presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and recurrent episodes of epistaxis for the past 6 months with a mass in the right nasal cavity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

JNA Adolescent male with unilateral nasal obstruction, epistaxis and mass are typical features of Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma JNA

Highyeild:

Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma It is a rare , benign tumour of the nasopharynx Site of origin : posterior part of nasal cavity close to the superior margin of sphenopalatine foramen Extent of growth : The tumour grows into the nasal cavity, nasopharynx and into the pterygopalatine fossa, running behind the posterior wall of maxillary sinus which is pushed forward as the tumour grows. Laterally, it extends into pterygomaxillary fossa and thence to infratemporal fossa and cheek Symptoms: Profuse, recurrent and spontaneous epistaxis Progressive nasal obstruction and denasal speech. Conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion. It occurs due to obstruction of the eustachian tube. Mass in the nasopharynx. Tumour is sessile, lobulated or smooth and obstructs one or both choanae. It is pink or purplish in colour. Consistency is firm but digital palpation should never be done until at the time of operation. Other clinical features like broadening of nasal bridge, proptosis, swelling of cheek, infratemporal fossa or involvement of IInd, IIIrd, IVth and VIth cranial nerves will depend on the extent of tumour Investigations: CT scan - Investigation of choice -To see the origin , extent of growth and bony erosions. MRI - To see the soft tissue extension and to differentiate intradural and extradural tumour Digital subtraction angiography - To see the extent , vascularity and feeding vessel Blood grouping and matching - To arrange blood intraoperatively , if required Treatment : Surgical excision is the treatment of choice Approaches: Transpalatine Transpalatine + Sublabial (Sardana’s approach) Lateral rhinotomy with medial maxillectomy (a) Via facial incision (b) Via degloving approach Endoscopic removal Transmaxillary (Le Fort I) approach Maxillary swing approach or facial translocation approach, or Wei’s operation Infratemporal fossa approach Intracranial–extracranial approach

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Antrochoanal polyp-It presents with unilateral nasal mass but no epistaxis Option: C. Coagulation disorder-It does not have mass in the nasal cavity Option: D. Allergic rhinitis-It does not present with nasal bleed

Extraedge:

Signs in juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma Antral sign/Holman – Miller sign: Anterior bowing of posterior maxillary wall. Hondusa sign: Increase distance between maxilla and mandible cheek swelling +. Frog face deformity: Tumor is in orbit and Ethmoid.

questions.text: A patient with papillary carcinoma thyroid underwent thyroidectomy. Post surgery she complains of hoarseness of voice. Which of the following steps in surgery could not have caused this symptom?

options.label: A
options.text: Ligation of vessels near superior pole of thyroid

options.label: D
options.text: Dissection close to the tubercle of zuckerkandl

questions.correct_answer: A. Ligation of vessels near superior pole of thyroid
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ligation of vessels near superior pole of thyroid Most of the surgeons prefer to take care and stay close to the gland rather than exploring the area to formally identify the nerve.

Highyeild:

Great care should be taken to identify and control the multiple vessels, which fan out from the superior pedicle to insert on the gland. Most, however, prefer to take care to stay close to the gland rather than exploring the area to formally identify the nerve.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Division of berry's ligament-a low Berry’s ligament, the nerve will be in close proximity to the gland at this crucial point. When Berry’s ligament is high, the nerve is often quite laterally placed in comparison Option: C. Dissecting around Beahr's triangle- Recurrent laryngeal nerve is identified in the Beahr’s triangle Option: D. Dissection close to the tubercle of zuckerkandl- Recurrent laryngeal nerve lies medial to it

Extraedge:

The relation of EBSLN to superior pole was defined based on the classification proposed by Cernea et al as follows: Type 1 in which the nerve crosses the artery more than 1 cm from the superior pole, Type 2a in which the EBSLN crosses the artery <1 cm and above the superior pole, and Type 2b in which the EBSLN crosses the artery below the superior pole. There is a significant increase in the incidence of Type 2 nerve in large volume glands, thereby making it more prone to injury during dissection. Hence, dissection of a large volume gland should be more meticulous than a low-volume gland. The EBSLN should be identified and preserved before ligating the superior pole vessels
